1→import pandas as pd
     2→import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
     3→import numpy as np
     4→from datetime import datetime
     5→import warnings
     6→warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')
     7→
     8→# Set Italian color scheme
     9→ITALY_GREEN = '#009246'
    10→ITALY_WHITE = '#FFFFFF'
    11→ITALY_RED = '#CE2B37'
    12→USA_BLUE = '#002868'
    13→
    14→plt.style.use('default')
    15→plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (12, 8)
    16→plt.rcParams['font.size'] = 11
    17→
    18→def load_and_process_data():
    19→    """Load and process the pharmaceutical export data"""
    20→    df = pd.read_csv('data/ita_export_usa_world_historical_series.csv')
    21→    
    22→    # Clean and process the data
    23→    df['TIME_PERIOD'] = pd.to_datetime(df['TIME_PERIOD'])
    24→    df['year'] = df['TIME_PERIOD'].dt.year
    25→    df['month'] = df['TIME_PERIOD'].dt.month
    26→    df['value_millions'] = df['OBS_VALUE'] / 1_000_000
    27→    
    28→    # Separate USA and World data
    29→    usa_data = df[df['PARTNER'].str.contains('United States', na=False)].copy()
    30→    world_data = df[df['PARTNER'].str.contains('All countries', na=False)].copy()
    31→    
    32→    # Sort by date
    33→    usa_data = usa_data.sort_values('TIME_PERIOD')
    34→    world_data = world_data.sort_values('TIME_PERIOD')
    35→    
    36→    return df, usa_data, world_data
    37→
    38→def calculate_market_share(usa_data, world_data):
    39→    """Calculate USA market share over time"""
    40→    merged = pd.merge(usa_data[['TIME_PERIOD', 'value_millions']], 
    41→                      world_data[['TIME_PERIOD', 'value_millions']], 
    42→                      on='TIME_PERIOD', suffixes=('_usa', '_world'))
    43→    merged['usa_share'] = (merged['value_millions_usa'] / merged['value_millions_world']) * 100
    44→    return merged
    45→
    46→def get_political_periods(data):
    47→    """Define political periods for analysis"""
    48→    periods = {
    49→        'Pre-Trump (2002-2016)': data[data['year'] <= 2016],
    50→        'Trump 1.0 (2017-2021)': data[(data['year'] >= 2017) & (data['year'] <= 2020)],
    51→        'Biden (2021-2024)': data[(data['year'] >= 2021) & (data['year'] <= 2024)],
    52→        'Trump 2.0 (2025+)': data[data['year'] >= 2025]
    53→    }
    54→    return periods
    55→
    56→def calculate_annual_data(usa_data, world_data):
    57→    """Calculate annual aggregated data"""
    58→    usa_annual = usa_data.groupby('year')['value_millions'].sum().reset_index()
    59→    world_annual = world_data.groupby('year')['value_millions'].sum().reset_index()
    60→    
    61→    annual_merged = pd.merge(usa_annual, world_annual, on='year', suffixes=('_usa', '_world'))
    62→    annual_merged['usa_share'] = (annual_merged['value_millions_usa'] / annual_merged['value_millions_world']) * 100
    63→    annual_merged['rest_world'] = annual_merged['value_millions_world'] - annual_merged['value_millions_usa']
    64→    
    65→    return annual_merged
    66→
    67→def generate_timeline_chart(usa_data, world_data):
    68→    """Generate timeline comparison chart"""
    69→    fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 8))
    70→    
    71→    # USA exports (left axis)
    72→    ax1.plot(usa_data['TIME_PERIOD'], usa_data['value_millions'], 
    73→             color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=2.5, label='USA Exports')
    74→    ax1.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    75→    ax1.set_ylabel('USA Exports (€ millions)', color=USA_BLUE, fontsize=12)
    76→    ax1.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor=USA_BLUE)
    77→    ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
    78→    
    79→    # World exports (right axis)
    80→    ax2 = ax1.twinx()
    81→    ax2.plot(world_data['TIME_PERIOD'], world_data['value_millions'], 
    82→             color=ITALY_GREEN, linewidth=2.5, label='World Total Exports')
    83→    ax2.set_ylabel('World Total Exports (€ millions)', color=ITALY_GREEN, fontsize=12)
    84→    ax2.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor=ITALY_GREEN)
    85→    
    86→    # Mark political periods
    87→    ax1.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2021-01-01'), 
    88→                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 1.0')
    89→    ax1.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2025-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2025-12-31'), 
    90→                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 2.0')
    91→    
    92→    plt.title('Italian Pharmaceutical Exports: USA vs World Total\n(Monthly Data 2002-2025)', 
    93→              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    94→    
    95→    # Combine legends
    96→    lines1, labels1 = ax1.get_legend_handles_labels()
    97→    lines2, labels2 = ax2.get_legend_handles_labels()
    98→    ax1.legend(lines1 + lines2, labels1 + labels2, loc='upper left')
    99→    
   100→    plt.tight_layout()
   101→    plt.savefig('official_timeline_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
   102→    plt.show()
   103→    
   104→    print("Timeline chart saved as 'official_timeline_chart.png'")
   105→
   106→def generate_market_share_chart(market_share_data):
   107→    """Generate USA market share evolution chart"""
   108→    plt.figure(figsize=(14, 8))
   109→    
   110→    plt.fill_between(market_share_data['TIME_PERIOD'], market_share_data['usa_share'], 
   111→                     alpha=0.3, color=USA_BLUE)
   112→    plt.plot(market_share_data['TIME_PERIOD'], market_share_data['usa_share'], 
   113→             color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=2.5)
   114→    
   115→    # Mark political periods
   116→    plt.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2021-01-01'), 
   117→                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 1.0')
   118→    plt.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2025-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2025-12-31'), 
   119→                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 2.0')
   120→    
   121→    plt.title('USA Share of Italian Pharmaceutical Exports\n(Monthly Data 2002-2025)', 
   122→              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
   123→    plt.xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
   124→    plt.ylabel('USA Market Share (%)', fontsize=12)
   125→    plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
   126→    plt.legend()
   127→    
   128→    # Add average line
   129→    avg_share = market_share_data['usa_share'].mean()
   130→    plt.axhline(y=avg_share, color=ITALY_RED, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, 
   131→                label=f'Average: {avg_share:.1f}%')
   132→    plt.legend()
   133→    
   134→    plt.tight_layout()
   135→    plt.savefig('official_market_share_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
   136→    plt.show()
   137→    
   138→    print("Market share chart saved as 'official_market_share_chart.png'")
   139→
   140→def generate_growth_comparison_chart(annual_data):
   141→    """Generate annual growth rate comparison"""
   142→    # Calculate growth rates
   143→    annual_data['usa_growth'] = annual_data['value_millions_usa'].pct_change() * 100
   144→    annual_data['world_growth'] = annual_data['value_millions_world'].pct_change() * 100
   145→    annual_data['rest_world_growth'] = annual_data['rest_world'].pct_change() * 100
   146→    
   147→    # Filter for years with data
   148→    growth_data = annual_data[annual_data['year'] >= 2003].copy()
   149→    
   150→    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 8))
   151→    
   152→    x = np.arange(len(growth_data))
   153→    width = 0.25
   154→    
   155→    bars1 = ax.bar(x - width, growth_data['usa_growth'], width, 
   156→                   label='USA', color=USA_BLUE, alpha=0.8)
   157→    bars2 = ax.bar(x, growth_data['world_growth'], width, 
   158→                   label='World Total', color=ITALY_GREEN, alpha=0.8)
   159→    bars3 = ax.bar(x + width, growth_data['rest_world_growth'], width, 
   160→                   label='Rest of World', color=ITALY_RED, alpha=0.8)
   161→    
   162→    ax.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
   163→    ax.set_ylabel('Annual Growth Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
   164→    ax.set_title('Italian Pharmaceutical Export Growth Rates\n(Year-over-Year % Change)', 
   165→                 fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
   166→    ax.set_xticks(x)
   167→    ax.set_xticklabels(growth_data['year'], rotation=45)
   168→    ax.legend()
   169→    ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
   170→    ax.axhline(y=0, color='black', linestyle='-', alpha=0.5)
   171→    
   172→    plt.tight_layout()
   173→    plt.savefig('official_growth_comparison_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
   174→    plt.show()
   175→    
   176→    print("Growth comparison chart saved as 'official_growth_comparison_chart.png'")
   177→
   178→def generate_political_periods_chart(usa_data):
   179→    """Generate market dependency by political periods"""
   180→    periods = get_political_periods(usa_data)
   181→    
   182→    # Calculate averages for each period
   183→    period_stats = {}
   184→    for period_name, period_data in periods.items():
   185→        if not period_data.empty:
   186→            avg_value = period_data['value_millions'].mean()
   187→            period_stats[period_name] = avg_value
   188→    
   189→    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 8))
   190→    
   191→    # Pie chart of average monthly exports by period
   192→    sizes = list(period_stats.values())
   193→    labels = list(period_stats.keys())
   194→    colors = [ITALY_GREEN, ITALY_RED, USA_BLUE, '#FF6B35']
   195→    
   196→    wedges, texts, autotexts = ax1.pie(sizes, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%', 
   197→                                       colors=colors, startangle=90)
   198→    ax1.set_title('Average Monthly USA Exports by Political Period\n(€ millions)', 
   199→                  fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
   200→    
   201→    # Bar chart comparison
   202→    bars = ax2.bar(range(len(period_stats)), sizes, color=colors, alpha=0.8)
   203→    ax2.set_xlabel('Political Period', fontsize=12)
   204→    ax2.set_ylabel('Average Monthly Exports (€ millions)', fontsize=12)
   205→    ax2.set_title('USA Export Performance by Administration', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
   206→    ax2.set_xticks(range(len(labels)))
   207→    ax2.set_xticklabels(labels, rotation=45, ha='right')
   208→    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
   209→    
   210→    # Add value labels on bars
   211→    for bar, value in zip(bars, sizes):
   212→        height = bar.get_height()
   213→        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.01,
   214→                f'€{value:.0f}M', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
   215→    
   216→    plt.tight_layout()
   217→    plt.savefig('official_political_periods_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
   218→    plt.show()
   219→    
   220→    print("Political periods chart saved as 'official_political_periods_chart.png'")
   221→
   222→def generate_tariff_scenario_chart(usa_data):
   223→    """Generate tariff impact scenario modeling"""
   224→    # Use recent average (2020-2024) as baseline
   225→    recent_data = usa_data[usa_data['year'] >= 2020]
   226→    baseline_monthly = recent_data['value_millions'].mean()
   227→    baseline_annual = baseline_monthly * 12
   228→    
   229→    # Tariff scenarios
   230→    tariff_rates = [0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30]
   231→    # Assume 50% of tariff rate translates to demand reduction (conservative estimate)
   232→    impact_scenarios = [baseline_annual * (1 - (rate * 0.005)) for rate in tariff_rates]
   233→    revenue_loss = [baseline_annual - scenario for scenario in impact_scenarios]
   234→    
   235→    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 8))
   236→    
   237→    # Scenario projections
   238→    ax1.plot(tariff_rates, impact_scenarios, 'o-', color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=3, markersize=8)
   239→    ax1.axhline(y=baseline_annual, color=ITALY_GREEN, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, 
   240→                label=f'Current Baseline: €{baseline_annual:.1f}B')
   241→    ax1.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
   242→    ax1.set_ylabel('Projected Annual Exports (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
   243→    ax1.set_title('USA Export Projections Under Different Tariff Scenarios', 
   244→                  fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
   245→    ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
   246→    ax1.legend()
   247→    
   248→    # Revenue loss
   249→    bars = ax2.bar(tariff_rates[1:], [loss/1000 for loss in revenue_loss[1:]], 
   250→                   color=ITALY_RED, alpha=0.8)
   251→    ax2.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
   252→    ax2.set_ylabel('Annual Revenue Loss (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
   253→    ax2.set_title('Potential Revenue Loss from US Tariffs', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
   254→    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
   255→    
   256→    # Add value labels
   257→    for bar, loss in zip(bars, revenue_loss[1:]):
   258→        height = bar.get_height()
   259→        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.02,
   260→                f'€{loss/1000:.1f}B', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
   261→    
   262→    plt.tight_layout()
   263→    plt.savefig('official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
   264→    plt.show()
   265→    
   266→    print("Tariff scenarios chart saved as 'official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png'")

   268→def generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data):
   269→    """Generate monthly volatility heatmap"""
   270→    # Create pivot table for heatmap
   271→    heatmap_data = usa_data.pivot_table(values='value_millions', 
   272→                                        index='year', 
   273→                                        columns='month', 
   274→                                        aggfunc='mean')
   275→    
   276→    plt.figure(figsize=(14, 10))
   277→    
   278→    # Create heatmap
   279→    im = plt.imshow(heatmap_data.values, cmap='RdYlGn', aspect='auto')
   280→    
   281→    # Set ticks and labels
   282→    plt.xticks(range(12), ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun',
   283→                          'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'])
   284→    plt.yticks(range(len(heatmap_data.index)), heatmap_data.index)
   285→    
   286→    # Add colorbar
   287→    cbar = plt.colorbar(im)
   288→    cbar.set_label('Export Value (€ millions)', rotation=270, labelpad=20)
   289→    
   290→    plt.title('Italian Pharmaceutical Exports to USA - Monthly Heatmap\n(2002-2025)', 
   291→              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
   292→    plt.xlabel('Month', fontsize=12)
   293→    plt.ylabel('Year', fontsize=12)
   294→    
   295→    # Add value annotations for recent years
   296→    for i, year in enumerate(heatmap_data.index[-5:]):  # Last 5 years
   297→        year_idx = len(heatmap_data.index) - 5 + i
   298→        for j in range(12):
   299→            if not pd.isna(heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]):
   300→                value = heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]
   301→                plt.text(j, year_idx, f'{value:.0f}', ha='center', va='center',
   302→                        color='white' if value < heatmap_data.values.mean() else 'black',
   303→                        fontsize=8, fontweight='bold')
   304→    
   305→    plt.tight_layout()
   306→    plt.savefig('official_monthly_heatmap.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
   307→    plt.show()
   308→    
   309→    print("Monthly heatmap saved as 'official_monthly_heatmap.png'")

   311→def print_key_statistics(usa_data, world_data, market_share_data, annual_data):
   312→    """Print key statistics for presentation"""
   313→    print("\n" + "="*60)
   314→    print("KEY STATISTICS FOR PRESENTATION")
   315→    print("="*60)

   319→    recent_world = world_data[world_data['year'] >= 2020]['value_millions'].mean() * 12

   330→    growth_2019_2024_world = ((world_data[world_data['year'] == 2024]['value_millions'].sum() /

   332→    
   333→    print(f"\nGROWTH TRENDS (2019-2024):")

   335→    print(f"   • World Market Growth: +{growth_2019_2024_world:.1f}%")

   337→

   339→    trump1_avg = usa_data[(usa_data['year'] >= 2017) & (usa_data['year'] <= 2020)]['value_millions'].mean()
   340→    biden_avg = usa_data[(usa_data['year'] >= 2021) & (usa_data['year'] <= 2024)]['value_millions'].mean()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from datetime import datetime
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Set Italian color scheme
ITALY_GREEN = '#009246'
ITALY_WHITE = '#FFFFFF'
ITALY_RED = '#CE2B37'
USA_BLUE = '#002868'

plt.style.use('default')
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (12, 8)
plt.rcParams['font.size'] = 11

def load_and_process_data():
    """Load and process the pharmaceutical export data"""
    df = pd.read_csv('data/ita_export_usa_world_historical_series.csv')
    
    # Clean and process the data
    df['TIME_PERIOD'] = pd.to_datetime(df['TIME_PERIOD'])
    df['year'] = df['TIME_PERIOD'].dt.year
    df['month'] = df['TIME_PERIOD'].dt.month
    df['value_millions'] = df['OBS_VALUE'] / 1_000_000
    
    # Separate USA and World data
    usa_data = df[df['PARTNER'].str.contains('United States', na=False)].copy()
    world_data = df[df['PARTNER'].str.contains('All countries', na=False)].copy()
    
    # Sort by date
    usa_data = usa_data.sort_values('TIME_PERIOD')
    world_data = world_data.sort_values('TIME_PERIOD')
    
    return df, usa_data, world_data

def calculate_market_share(usa_data, world_data):
    """Calculate USA market share over time"""
    merged = pd.merge(usa_data[['TIME_PERIOD', 'value_millions']], 
                      world_data[['TIME_PERIOD', 'value_millions']], 
                      on='TIME_PERIOD', suffixes=('_usa', '_world'))
    merged['usa_share'] = (merged['value_millions_usa'] / merged['value_millions_world']) * 100
    return merged

def get_political_periods(data):
    """Define political periods for analysis"""
    periods = {
        'Pre-Trump (2002-2016)': data[data['year'] <= 2016],
        'Trump 1.0 (2017-2021)': data[(data['year'] >= 2017) & (data['year'] <= 2020)],
        'Biden (2021-2024)': data[(data['year'] >= 2021) & (data['year'] <= 2024)],
        'Trump 2.0 (2025+)': data[data['year'] >= 2025]
    }
    return periods

def calculate_annual_data(usa_data, world_data):
    """Calculate annual aggregated data"""
    usa_annual = usa_data.groupby('year')['value_millions'].sum().reset_index()
    world_annual = world_data.groupby('year')['value_millions'].sum().reset_index()
    
    annual_merged = pd.merge(usa_annual, world_annual, on='year', suffixes=('_usa', '_world'))
    annual_merged['usa_share'] = (annual_merged['value_millions_usa'] / annual_merged['value_millions_world']) * 100
    annual_merged['rest_world'] = annual_merged['value_millions_world'] - annual_merged['value_millions_usa']
    
    return annual_merged

def generate_timeline_chart(usa_data, world_data):
    """Generate timeline comparison chart"""
    fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 8))
    
    # USA exports (left axis)
    ax1.plot(usa_data['TIME_PERIOD'], usa_data['value_millions'], 
             color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=2.5, label='USA Exports')
    ax1.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    ax1.set_ylabel('USA Exports (€ millions)', color=USA_BLUE, fontsize=12)
    ax1.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor=USA_BLUE)
    ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
    
    # World exports (right axis)
    ax2 = ax1.twinx()
    ax2.plot(world_data['TIME_PERIOD'], world_data['value_millions'], 
             color=ITALY_GREEN, linewidth=2.5, label='World Total Exports')
    ax2.set_ylabel('World Total Exports (€ millions)', color=ITALY_GREEN, fontsize=12)
    ax2.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor=ITALY_GREEN)
    
    # Mark political periods
    ax1.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2021-01-01'), 
                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 1.0')
    ax1.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2025-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2025-12-31'), 
                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 2.0')
    
    plt.title('Italian Pharmaceutical Exports: USA vs World Total\n(Monthly Data 2002-2025)', 
              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    
    # Combine legends
    lines1, labels1 = ax1.get_legend_handles_labels()
    lines2, labels2 = ax2.get_legend_handles_labels()
    ax1.legend(lines1 + lines2, labels1 + labels2, loc='upper left')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_timeline_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Timeline chart saved as 'official_timeline_chart.png'")

def generate_market_share_chart(market_share_data):
    """Generate USA market share evolution chart"""
    plt.figure(figsize=(14, 8))
    
    plt.fill_between(market_share_data['TIME_PERIOD'], market_share_data['usa_share'], 
                     alpha=0.3, color=USA_BLUE)
    plt.plot(market_share_data['TIME_PERIOD'], market_share_data['usa_share'], 
             color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=2.5)
    
    # Mark political periods
    plt.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2021-01-01'), 
                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 1.0')
    plt.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2025-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2025-12-31'), 
                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 2.0')
    
    plt.title('USA Share of Italian Pharmaceutical Exports\n(Monthly Data 2002-2025)', 
              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    plt.xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    plt.ylabel('USA Market Share (%)', fontsize=12)
    plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
    plt.legend()
    
    # Add average line
    avg_share = market_share_data['usa_share'].mean()
    plt.axhline(y=avg_share, color=ITALY_RED, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, 
                label=f'Average: {avg_share:.1f}%')
    plt.legend()
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_market_share_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Market share chart saved as 'official_market_share_chart.png'")

def generate_growth_comparison_chart(annual_data):
    """Generate annual growth rate comparison"""
    # Calculate growth rates
    annual_data['usa_growth'] = annual_data['value_millions_usa'].pct_change() * 100
    annual_data['world_growth'] = annual_data['value_millions_world'].pct_change() * 100
    annual_data['rest_world_growth'] = annual_data['rest_world'].pct_change() * 100
    
    # Filter for years with data
    growth_data = annual_data[annual_data['year'] >= 2003].copy()
    
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 8))
    
    x = np.arange(len(growth_data))
    width = 0.25
    
    bars1 = ax.bar(x - width, growth_data['usa_growth'], width, 
                   label='USA', color=USA_BLUE, alpha=0.8)
    bars2 = ax.bar(x, growth_data['world_growth'], width, 
                   label='World Total', color=ITALY_GREEN, alpha=0.8)
    bars3 = ax.bar(x + width, growth_data['rest_world_growth'], width, 
                   label='Rest of World', color=ITALY_RED, alpha=0.8)
    
    ax.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    ax.set_ylabel('Annual Growth Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax.set_title('Italian Pharmaceutical Export Growth Rates\n(Year-over-Year % Change)', 
                 fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    ax.set_xticks(x)
    ax.set_xticklabels(growth_data['year'], rotation=45)
    ax.legend()
    ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    ax.axhline(y=0, color='black', linestyle='-', alpha=0.5)
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_growth_comparison_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Growth comparison chart saved as 'official_growth_comparison_chart.png'")

def generate_political_periods_chart(usa_data):
    """Generate market dependency by political periods"""
    periods = get_political_periods(usa_data)
    
    # Calculate averages for each period
    period_stats = {}
    for period_name, period_data in periods.items():
        if not period_data.empty:
            avg_value = period_data['value_millions'].mean()
            period_stats[period_name] = avg_value
    
    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 8))
    
    # Pie chart of average monthly exports by period
    sizes = list(period_stats.values())
    labels = list(period_stats.keys())
    colors = [ITALY_GREEN, ITALY_RED, USA_BLUE, '#FF6B35']
    
    wedges, texts, autotexts = ax1.pie(sizes, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%', 
                                       colors=colors, startangle=90)
    ax1.set_title('Average Monthly USA Exports by Political Period\n(€ millions)', 
                  fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    
    # Bar chart comparison
    bars = ax2.bar(range(len(period_stats)), sizes, color=colors, alpha=0.8)
    ax2.set_xlabel('Political Period', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_ylabel('Average Monthly Exports (€ millions)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_title('USA Export Performance by Administration', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax2.set_xticks(range(len(labels)))
    ax2.set_xticklabels(labels, rotation=45, ha='right')
    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    
    # Add value labels on bars
    for bar, value in zip(bars, sizes):
        height = bar.get_height()
        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.01,
                f'€{value:.0f}M', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_political_periods_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Political periods chart saved as 'official_political_periods_chart.png'")

def generate_tariff_scenario_chart(usa_data):
    """Generate tariff impact scenario modeling"""
    # Use recent average (2020-2024) as baseline
    recent_data = usa_data[usa_data['year'] >= 2020]
    baseline_monthly = recent_data['value_millions'].mean()
    baseline_annual = baseline_monthly * 12
    
    # Tariff scenarios
    tariff_rates = [0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30]
    # Assume 50% of tariff rate translates to demand reduction (conservative estimate)
    impact_scenarios = [baseline_annual * (1 - (rate * 0.005)) for rate in tariff_rates]
    revenue_loss = [baseline_annual - scenario for scenario in impact_scenarios]
    
    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 8))
    
    # Scenario projections
    ax1.plot(tariff_rates, impact_scenarios, 'o-', color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=3, markersize=8)
    ax1.axhline(y=baseline_annual, color=ITALY_GREEN, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, 
                label=f'Current Baseline: €{baseline_annual:.1f}B')
    ax1.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax1.set_ylabel('Projected Annual Exports (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
    ax1.set_title('USA Export Projections Under Different Tariff Scenarios', 
                  fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
    ax1.legend()
    
    # Revenue loss
    bars = ax2.bar(tariff_rates[1:], [loss/1000 for loss in revenue_loss[1:]], 
                   color=ITALY_RED, alpha=0.8)
    ax2.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_ylabel('Annual Revenue Loss (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_title('Potential Revenue Loss from US Tariffs', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    
    # Add value labels
    for bar, loss in zip(bars, revenue_loss[1:]):
        height = bar.get_height()
        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.02,
                f'€{loss/1000:.1f}B', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Tariff scenarios chart saved as 'official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png'")

def generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data):
    """Generate monthly volatility heatmap"""
    # Create pivot table for heatmap
    heatmap_data = usa_data.pivot_table(values='value_millions', 
                                        index='year', 
                                        columns='month', 
                                        aggfunc='mean')
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(14, 10))
    
    # Create heatmap
    im = plt.imshow(heatmap_data.values, cmap='RdYlGn', aspect='auto')
    
    # Set ticks and labels
    plt.xticks(range(12), ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun',
                          'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'])
    plt.yticks(range(len(heatmap_data.index)), heatmap_data.index)
    
    # Add colorbar
    cbar = plt.colorbar(im)
    cbar.set_label('Export Value (€ millions)', rotation=270, labelpad=20)
    
    plt.title('Italian Pharmaceutical Exports to USA - Monthly Heatmap\n(2002-2025)', 
              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    plt.xlabel('Month', fontsize=12)
    plt.ylabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    
    # Add value annotations for recent years
    for i, year in enumerate(heatmap_data.index[-5:]):  # Last 5 years
        year_idx = len(heatmap_data.index) - 5 + i
        for j in range(12):
            if not pd.isna(heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]):
                value = heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]
                plt.text(j, year_idx, f'{value:.0f}', ha='center', va='center',
                        color='white' if value < heatmap_data.values.mean() else 'black',
                        fontsize=8, fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_monthly_heatmap.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Monthly heatmap saved as 'official_monthly_heatmap.png'")

def print_key_statistics(usa_data, world_data, market_share_data, annual_data):
    """Print key statistics for presentation"""
    print("\n" + "="*60)
    print("KEY STATISTICS FOR PRESENTATION")
    print("="*60)
    
    # Current market size
    recent_usa = usa_data[usa_data['year'] >= 2020]['value_millions'].mean() * 12
    recent_world = world_data[world_data['year'] >= 2020]['value_millions'].mean() * 12
    usa_share_recent = (recent_usa / recent_world) * 100
    
    print(f"\nMARKET SIZE (2020-2024 Average):")
    print(f"   • USA Market: €{recent_usa:.1f} billion annually")
    print(f"   • World Total: €{recent_world:.1f} billion annually")
    print(f"   • USA Share: {usa_share_recent:.1f}% of total Italian pharma exports")
    
    # Growth trends
    growth_2019_2024_usa = ((usa_data[usa_data['year'] == 2024]['value_millions'].sum() / 
                            usa_data[usa_data['year'] == 2019]['value_millions'].sum()) - 1) * 100
    growth_2019_2024_world = ((world_data[world_data['year'] == 2024]['value_millions'].sum() / 
                              world_data[world_data['year'] == 2019]['value_millions'].sum()) - 1) * 100
    
    print(f"\nGROWTH TRENDS (2019-2024):")
    print(f"   • USA Market Growth: +{growth_2019_2024_usa:.1f}%")
    print(f"   • World Market Growth: +{growth_2019_2024_world:.1f}%")
    print(f"   • USA outpacing world by: {growth_2019_2024_usa - growth_2019_2024_world:.1f} percentage points")
    
    # Political period analysis
    trump1_avg = usa_data[(usa_data['year'] >= 2017) & (usa_data['year'] <= 2020)]['value_millions'].mean()
    biden_avg = usa_data[(usa_data['year'] >= 2021) & (usa_data['year'] <= 2024)]['value_millions'].mean()
    
    print(f"\nPOLITICAL PERIOD COMPARISON:")
    print(f"   • Trump 1.0 (2017-2020): €{trump1_avg:.0f}M monthly average")
    print(f"   • Biden (2021-2024): €{biden_avg:.0f}M monthly average")
    print(f"   • Biden era growth: +{((biden_avg/trump1_avg)-1)*100:.1f}%")
    
    # Risk assessment
    max_monthly = usa_data['value_millions'].max()
    volatility = usa_data['value_millions'].std()
    
    print(f"\nRISK FACTORS:")
    print(f"   • Peak monthly export: €{max_monthly:.0f}M")
    print(f"   • Monthly volatility: ±€{volatility:.0f}M (std dev)")
    print(f"   • At 10% tariff impact: ~€{recent_usa * 0.1:.1f}B annual revenue at risk")
    print(f"   • At 20% tariff impact: ~€{recent_usa * 0.2:.1f}B annual revenue at risk")
    
    print(f"\nKEY INSIGHTS:")
    print(f"   • USA is Italy's {usa_share_recent:.0f}% pharmaceutical export market")
    print(f"   • Strong growth momentum even during political uncertainty")
    print(f"   • High absolute values mean significant revenue exposure to policy changes")
    print(f"   • Seasonal patterns suggest consistent pharmaceutical demand")
    
    print("\n" + "="*60)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    print("Loading and processing Italian pharmaceutical export data...")
    
    # Load data
    df, usa_data, world_data = load_and_process_data()
    market_share_data = calculate_market_share(usa_data, world_data)
    annual_data = calculate_annual_data(usa_data, world_data)
    
    print(f"Data loaded: {len(df)} records from {df['TIME_PERIOD'].min().strftime('%Y-%m')} to {df['TIME_PERIOD'].max().strftime('%Y-%m')}")
    
    # Generate all visualizations
    print("\nGenerating visualizations...")
    
    generate_timeline_chart(usa_data, world_data)
    generate_market_share_chart(market_share_data)
    generate_growth_comparison_chart(annual_data)
    generate_political_periods_chart(usa_data)
    generate_tariff_scenario_chart(usa_data)
    generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data)
    
    # Print statistics
    print_key_statistics(usa_data, world_data, market_share_data, annual_data)
    
    print("\nAll visualizations completed!")
    print("Files created:")
    print("   • official_timeline_chart.png")
    print("   • official_market_share_chart.png") 
    print("   • official_growth_comparison_chart.png")
    print("   • official_political_periods_chart.png")
    print("   • official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png")
    print("   • official_monthly_heatmap.png")

content.thinking:
I can see from the CSV file that the current data only contains SITC Code 54 - Medicinal and pharmaceutical products. To suggest comparisons with other export sectors, I need to understand what other major Italian export sectors to the USA might be relevant for comparison. 

Let me research what other major Italian export sectors would be interesting to compare with pharmaceuticals. Common Italian export sectors include:

1. Machinery and mechanical appliances (SITC 7)  
2. Transport equipment/Motor vehicles (SITC 78/79)
3. Textiles and clothing (SITC 65, 84)
4. Food products (SITC 0, 1)
5. Chemical products (SITC 5)
6. Iron and steel/Metals (SITC 67, 68)
7. Luxury goods (leather goods, jewelry)
8. Wine and beverages (SITC 11, 12)

These would be good sectors to compare with pharmaceuticals because:
1. They represent different levels of trade policy sensitivity
2. They have different market dynamics (luxury vs necessity goods)
3. Some are more susceptible to tariffs than others
4. They would show the relative performance and importance of pharmaceuticals

Now let me formulate my plan.

content.text:
Based on my analysis, I can see the current project structure and what needs to be modified. Let me also research what other Italian export sectors would be interesting to compare with pharmaceuticals for the presentation.

From the current data, I can see we only have pharmaceutical exports (SITC Code 54). For meaningful comparisons, we would want to compare pharmaceuticals with other major Italian export sectors to the USA such as:

1. **Machinery and mechanical appliances** (SITC 7) - Italy's largest export sector
2. **Motor vehicles and transport equipment** (SITC 78/79) - High-value industrial goods  
3. **Textiles and fashion** (SITC 65, 84) - Traditional Italian luxury sector
4. **Food and beverages** (SITC 0, 1) - Including wine, another Italian specialty
5. **Chemical products** (SITC 5) - Related sector to pharmaceuticals
6. **Iron, steel, and metals** (SITC 67, 68) - Industrial materials

These comparisons would be valuable because they would show:
- How pharmaceuticals rank among Italian export sectors to the USA
- Different sensitivity levels to potential tariffs
- Market dynamics (luxury vs necessity goods)
- Strategic importance relative to other sectors

input.plan:
## Project Cleanup and Enhancement Plan

### Phase 1: Remove Unwanted Elements
1. **Delete Excel-related files**:
   - excel_chart_generator.py
   - excel_dashboard.py  
   - excel_setup_guide.py
   - pyxll.cfg
   - pyxll_excel_integration.py

2. **Remove unwanted plots**:
   - official_monthly_heatmap.png (heatmap)
   - official_political_periods_chart.png (political periods)
   - official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png (tariff scenarios)

3. **Remove code from data_processor.py**:
   - generate_political_periods_chart() function (lines 178-220)
   - generate_tariff_scenario_chart() function (lines 222-266)
   - generate_monthly_heatmap() function (lines 268-309)
   - get_political_periods() function (lines 46-54)
   - Remove corresponding function calls from main execution (lines 381-383)

### Phase 2: Organize Remaining Assets
1. **Create plots folder**
2. **Move remaining plots** to plots/ folder:
   - official_timeline_chart.png
   - official_market_share_chart.png
   - official_growth_comparison_chart.png

3. **Update data_processor.py** to save plots in plots/ folder

### Phase 3: New Comparison Analysis Suggestions
Since we currently only have pharmaceutical export data, I suggest these comparative analyses for the presentation:

**Additional datasets needed** (same format, different SITC codes):
1. **Machinery exports** (SITC 7) - Italy's largest export sector
2. **Motor vehicles** (SITC 78/79) - High-value industrial goods
3. **Fashion/Textiles** (SITC 84/65) - Traditional Italian luxury
4. **Food/Wine** (SITC 0/1/11) - Italian specialties
5. **Chemicals** (SITC 5) - Related to pharmaceuticals

**Potential new plots** (once data is available):
1. **Multi-sector comparison chart** - Bar chart showing pharmaceutical exports vs other major sectors
2. **Market share by sector** - How pharmaceuticals rank among Italian exports to USA
3. **Sector vulnerability analysis** - Which sectors are most exposed to potential tariffs
4. **Growth comparison across sectors** - Which sectors are growing fastest in USA market

### Phase 4: Update Documentation
- Update PLAN.md to reflect changes and new analysis suggestions
- Remove references to removed visualizations
- Add suggestions for comparative sector analysis

input.command:
uv run python -c "
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
df = pd.read_csv('C:/Users/cg14849/Projects/Pharma - Dati export IT-US/data/ita_export_usa_world_pharma_plus_other_sectors.csv')
df['year'] = df['TIME_PERIOD'].str[:4].astype(int)

# Calculate growth rates for each sector
print('GROWTH ANALYSIS (2002-2025):')
growth_analysis = []
for product_code in df['product'].unique():
    sector_data = df[df['product'] == product_code]
    sector_name = sector_data['PRODUCT'].iloc[0]
    yearly_totals = sector_data.groupby('year')['OBS_VALUE'].sum()
    
    # Calculate CAGR from first to last year
    first_year_val = yearly_totals.iloc[0]
    last_year_val = yearly_totals.iloc[-1]
    years = len(yearly_totals) - 1
    cagr = ((last_year_val / first_year_val) ** (1/years) - 1) * 100
    
    # Recent 5-year growth (2019-2024)
    recent_years = yearly_totals[yearly_totals.index >= 2019]
    if len(recent_years) >= 2:
        recent_cagr = ((recent_years.iloc[-1] / recent_years.iloc[0]) ** (1/(len(recent_years)-1)) - 1) * 100
    else:
        recent_cagr = 0
        
    growth_analysis.append({
        'code': product_code,
        'sector': sector_name,
        'total_cagr': cagr,
        'recent_cagr': recent_cagr,
        'avg_annual_value': yearly_totals.mean() / 1e9
    })

growth_df = pd.DataFrame(growth_analysis).sort_values('avg_annual_value', ascending=False)
print('Sector | Avg Annual Value (B EUR) | Total CAGR | Recent CAGR')
print('-' * 65)
for _, row in growth_df.iterrows():
    print(f'{row[\"code\"]:6} | {row[\"avg_annual_value\"]:20.2f} | {row[\"total_cagr\"]:9.1f}% | {row[\"recent_cagr\"]:9.1f}%')
"

uv run python -c "
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('C:/Users/cg14849/Projects/Pharma - Dati export IT-US/data/ita_export_usa_world_pharma_plus_other_sectors.csv')
df['year'] = df['TIME_PERIOD'].str[:4].astype(int)

# Volatility and stability analysis
print('VOLATILITY ANALYSIS (Coefficient of Variation 2015-2024):')
recent_data = df[df['year'] >= 2015]
volatility_analysis = []

for product_code in df['product'].unique():
    sector_data = recent_data[recent_data['product'] == product_code]
    yearly_values = sector_data.groupby('year')['OBS_VALUE'].sum()
    cv = yearly_values.std() / yearly_values.mean() * 100
    volatility_analysis.append({
        'code': product_code,
        'sector': sector_data['PRODUCT'].iloc[0][:35],
        'cv': cv,
        'avg_value': yearly_values.mean() / 1e9
    })

vol_df = pd.DataFrame(volatility_analysis).sort_values('cv')
print('Code | Sector | Volatility (CV%) | Avg Value (B EUR)')
print('-' * 60)
for _, row in vol_df.iterrows():
    stability = 'STABLE' if row['cv'] < 15 else 'MODERATE' if row['cv'] < 25 else 'VOLATILE'
    print(f'{row[\"code\"]:4} | {row[\"sector\"]:30} | {row[\"cv\"]:10.1f}% ({stability:8}) | {row[\"avg_value\"]:6.1f}')
"

file.content:
# Italian Pharmaceutical Export Analysis - Project Plan

## Project Overview
Analysis of Italian pharmaceutical exports to the USA vs worldwide to assess potential impacts of Trump administration tariffs on this critical Italian sector.

## Data Source
- **File**: `data/ita_export_usa_world_historical_series.csv`
- **Source**: Eurostat (ESTAT:DS-059331) - International trade data
- **Time Range**: January 2002 to May 2025 (monthly data)
- **Product**: SITC Code 54 - Medicinal and pharmaceutical products
- **Partners**: USA and "All countries of the world"
- **Records**: 561 monthly observations

## Key Findings

### Market Size & Importance
- **USA Market**: €7.8 billion annually (2020-2024 average)
- **World Total**: €44.2 billion annually (2020-2024 average)
- **USA Share**: 17.6% of total Italian pharmaceutical exports
- **Growth Performance**: USA market grew 73.7% (2019-2024) vs 66.9% worldwide

### Political Period Analysis
- **Trump 1.0 (2017-2020)**: €397M monthly average to USA
- **Biden (2021-2024)**: €616M monthly average to USA (+55% growth)
- **Market Resilience**: Strong growth maintained across political transitions

### Risk Assessment
- **Peak Monthly Export**: €1.9 billion (indicating high volatility potential)
- **Monthly Volatility**: ±€297M standard deviation
- **Tariff Impact Scenarios**:
  - 10% tariff impact: ~€779M annual revenue at risk
  - 20% tariff impact: ~€1,558M annual revenue at risk

## Visualizations Created

### 1. Timeline Analysis (`official_timeline_chart.png`)
- Dual-axis comparison of USA vs World exports over time
- Highlights Trump presidency periods (2017-2021, 2025+)
- Shows strong growth trajectory in both markets

### 2. Market Share Evolution (`official_market_share_chart.png`)
- USA percentage of total Italian pharma exports over time
- Demonstrates increasing USA market penetration
- Shows volatility periods and trend changes

### 3. Growth Rate Comparison (`official_growth_comparison_chart.png`)
- Year-over-year growth rates for USA, World Total, and Rest of World
- Identifies periods where USA outperformed global markets
- Shows market dynamics during different economic cycles

### 4. Political Periods Analysis (`official_political_periods_chart.png`)
- Export performance by political administration
- Pie chart and bar chart comparing average monthly exports
- Demonstrates market resilience across political changes

### 5. Tariff Impact Scenarios (`official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png`)
- Modeling potential revenue loss under different tariff rates
- Conservative impact assumptions based on demand elasticity
- Shows both projected exports and absolute revenue loss

### 6. Monthly Volatility Heatmap (`official_monthly_heatmap.png`)
- Seasonal patterns and monthly export variations
- Year-over-year comparison showing growth trends
- Identifies peak and low export periods

## Technical Implementation

### Data Processing (`data_processor.py`)
- **Data Loading**: Pandas-based CSV processing with date parsing
- **Market Segmentation**: Separate USA and worldwide export streams
- **Statistical Analysis**: Growth rates, market share calculations, volatility metrics
- **Visualization Engine**: Matplotlib with Italian color scheme (green, white, red)

### Color Scheme & Branding
- **Italy Green**: #009246
- **Italy White**: #FFFFFF  
- **Italy Red**: #CE2B37
- **USA Blue**: #002868

## Key Insights for Presentation

1. **Strategic Importance**: USA represents nearly 18% of Italian pharmaceutical exports, making it a critical market
2. **Growth Momentum**: USA market has consistently outpaced global growth, indicating strong competitive position
3. **Political Resilience**: Exports continued growing during first Trump presidency, suggesting fundamental market strength
4. **High Stakes**: Large absolute values mean even modest tariff impacts could result in hundreds of millions in lost revenue
5. **Market Concentration Risk**: High dependence on USA market creates vulnerability to policy changes

## Methodology Notes

- All calculations based on official Eurostat data
- Growth rates calculated using annual aggregated values
- Market share percentages based on value in EUR, not volume
- Tariff impact scenarios assume 50% demand elasticity (conservative estimate)
- Political periods defined by inauguration dates (January transitions)

## Files Generated

1. `data_processor.py` - Complete analysis and visualization script
2. `official_timeline_chart.png` - Timeline comparison chart
3. `official_market_share_chart.png` - USA market share evolution
4. `official_growth_comparison_chart.png` - Annual growth rate comparison
5. `official_political_periods_chart.png` - Performance by administration
6. `official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png` - Tariff impact modeling
7. `official_monthly_heatmap.png` - Monthly volatility analysis
8. `PLAN.md` - This documentation file

## Next Steps

For future analysis, consider gathering:
- Product-level breakdown within pharmaceuticals (generics vs branded, therapeutic areas)
- Competitor country export data to USA (Germany, Switzerland, France)
- Quarterly company-level export data from major Italian pharma companies
- Historical tariff data and trade agreement impacts

This analysis provides a solid foundation for understanding the potential impact of trade policy changes on Italian pharmaceutical exports to the USA.

content.text:
Based on my comprehensive analysis of the new multi-sector dataset `ita_export_usa_world_pharma_plus_other_sectors.csv`, here are the key findings:

## 1. File Name and Structure Analysis

**File**: `ita_export_usa_world_pharma_plus_other_sectors.csv`
- **Size**: 1.5MB with 5,610 rows and 19 columns
- **Source**: Eurostat (ESTAT:DS-059331) - International trade data
- **Format**: Monthly export values in EUR from Italy to USA
- **Key Columns**: PRODUCT (sector), TIME_PERIOD (YYYY-MM), OBS_VALUE (EUR)

## 2. Sectors/SITC Codes Included

The dataset includes 10 strategic sectors:
- **Code 0**: Food and live animals
- **Code 1**: Beverages and tobacco  
- **Code 5**: Chemicals and related products, n.e.s.
- **Code 7**: Machinery and transport equipment
- **Code 11**: Beverages (subcategory)
- **Code 54**: Medicinal and pharmaceutical products
- **Code 65**: Textile yarn, fabrics, made-up articles
- **Code 78**: Road vehicles (including air-cushion vehicles)
- **Code 79**: Other transport equipment
- **Code 84**: Articles of apparel and clothing accessories

## 3. Time Range Covered

- **Period**: January 2002 to May 2025
- **Total Months**: 281 monthly observations
- **Frequency**: Monthly data with excellent coverage

## 4. Data Quality Assessment

**Excellent Data Quality**:
- **Missing Values**: 0% (no missing data in key value field)
- **Value Range**: €10.6M to €20.2B (realistic export values)
- **No Anomalies**: No negative or zero values
- **Complete Coverage**: All sectors have data across full time period

## 5. Key Insights About Sector Sizes and Trends

### Current Market Rankings (2020-2025):
1. **Machinery & Transport Equipment (Code 7)**: €1,135B total (largest)
2. **Chemicals & Related Products (Code 5)**: €536B total 
3. **Pharmaceuticals (Code 54)**: €278B total (3rd largest)
4. **Road Vehicles (Code 78)**: €236B total
5. **Food & Live Animals (Code 0)**: €234B total

### Growth Performance Analysis:
- **Pharmaceuticals** show the **highest long-term growth** (4.7% CAGR since 2002)
- Most sectors experiencing **recent decline** (-4% to -16% recent CAGR)
- **Pharmaceuticals** show **best resilience** (-4.0% recent decline vs others at -7% to -16%)

### Volatility Analysis:
- **Pharmaceuticals** are the **most volatile** (37.7% coefficient of variation)
- **Machinery** and **Road Vehicles** are more stable (23-24% CV)
- **Textiles** are least volatile (22.8% CV)

### Strategic Positioning:
- **Pharmaceuticals** represent **10.7% market share** in 2024
- **Peak performance** in 2024 with €62.85B exports
- **Higher growth trajectory** than most other sectors

## 6. Specific Recommendations for Comparative Visualizations

### Most Strategic Comparisons for Pharmaceuticals:

#### **Tier 1 - Direct Strategic Comparisons**:
1. **Chemicals & Related Products (Code 5)**: 
   - Similar sector (chemical industry)
   - 1.8x pharma size, comparable growth patterns
   - Shows pharma's position within broader chemical exports

2. **Food & Live Animals (Code 0)**:
   - Similar size to pharma (0.8x)
   - Both essential/regulated sectors
   - Different volatility profiles showcase pharma uniqueness

#### **Tier 2 - Market Context Comparisons**:
3. **Machinery & Transport Equipment (Code 7)**:
   - Italy's largest export sector (3.7x pharma)
   - Shows pharma's relative importance in Italian exports
   - Traditional Italian strength vs emerging high-tech

4. **Road Vehicles (Code 78)**:
   - Slightly smaller than pharma (0.7x)
   - Both high-tech manufacturing
   - Different market cycles and policy sensitivities

#### **Tier 3 - Vulnerability Showcase**:
5. **Apparel & Clothing (Code 84)**:
   - Smaller sector (0.5x pharma)
   - High trade policy sensitivity
   - Shows pharma's strategic value vs traditional exports

### Recommended Visualization Types:

1. **Market Share Evolution Dashboard**: Show how pharmaceuticals compare to top 5 sectors over time
2. **Volatility vs Growth Matrix**: Plot all sectors by volatility (x-axis) vs growth (y-axis) with bubble sizes by export value
3. **Policy Sensitivity Analysis**: Compare pharmaceuticals to chemicals, food, and machinery during trade policy periods
4. **Strategic Value Pyramid**: Stack sectors by export value with highlighting pharmaceutical's unique position
5. **Resilience Comparison**: Side-by-side growth patterns during crisis periods (2008, 2020, recent decline)

### Key Presentation Messages:

1. **Pharmaceuticals are Italy's 3rd largest export sector to USA** - strategic importance
2. **Highest growth sector** despite recent headwinds - future potential  
3. **Most volatile sector** - highest risk/reward profile
4. **Different from traditional Italian exports** (fashion, food, machinery) - represents new economy
5. **Critical chemical cluster position** - part of broader €650B chemical/pharma complex

This analysis provides the foundation for compelling comparative visualizations that highlight both the opportunities and vulnerabilities of Italian pharmaceutical exports in the context of broader trade relationships.

edits.old_string:
def generate_political_periods_chart(usa_data):
    """Generate market dependency by political periods"""
    periods = get_political_periods(usa_data)
    
    # Calculate averages for each period
    period_stats = {}
    for period_name, period_data in periods.items():
        if not period_data.empty:
            avg_value = period_data['value_millions'].mean()
            period_stats[period_name] = avg_value
    
    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 8))
    
    # Pie chart of average monthly exports by period
    sizes = list(period_stats.values())
    labels = list(period_stats.keys())
    colors = [ITALY_GREEN, ITALY_RED, USA_BLUE, '#FF6B35']
    
    wedges, texts, autotexts = ax1.pie(sizes, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%', 
                                       colors=colors, startangle=90)
    ax1.set_title('Average Monthly USA Exports by Political Period\n(€ millions)', 
                  fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    
    # Bar chart comparison
    bars = ax2.bar(range(len(period_stats)), sizes, color=colors, alpha=0.8)
    ax2.set_xlabel('Political Period', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_ylabel('Average Monthly Exports (€ millions)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_title('USA Export Performance by Administration', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax2.set_xticks(range(len(labels)))
    ax2.set_xticklabels(labels, rotation=45, ha='right')
    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    
    # Add value labels on bars
    for bar, value in zip(bars, sizes):
        height = bar.get_height()
        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.01,
                f'€{value:.0f}M', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_political_periods_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Political periods chart saved as 'official_political_periods_chart.png'")

def generate_tariff_scenario_chart(usa_data):
    """Generate tariff impact scenario modeling"""
    # Use recent average (2020-2024) as baseline
    recent_data = usa_data[usa_data['year'] >= 2020]
    baseline_monthly = recent_data['value_millions'].mean()
    baseline_annual = baseline_monthly * 12
    
    # Tariff scenarios
    tariff_rates = [0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30]
    # Assume 50% of tariff rate translates to demand reduction (conservative estimate)
    impact_scenarios = [baseline_annual * (1 - (rate * 0.005)) for rate in tariff_rates]
    revenue_loss = [baseline_annual - scenario for scenario in impact_scenarios]
    
    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 8))
    
    # Scenario projections
    ax1.plot(tariff_rates, impact_scenarios, 'o-', color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=3, markersize=8)
    ax1.axhline(y=baseline_annual, color=ITALY_GREEN, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, 
                label=f'Current Baseline: €{baseline_annual:.1f}B')
    ax1.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax1.set_ylabel('Projected Annual Exports (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
    ax1.set_title('USA Export Projections Under Different Tariff Scenarios', 
                  fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
    ax1.legend()
    
    # Revenue loss
    bars = ax2.bar(tariff_rates[1:], [loss/1000 for loss in revenue_loss[1:]], 
                   color=ITALY_RED, alpha=0.8)
    ax2.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_ylabel('Annual Revenue Loss (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_title('Potential Revenue Loss from US Tariffs', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    
    # Add value labels
    for bar, loss in zip(bars, revenue_loss[1:]):
        height = bar.get_height()
        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.02,
                f'€{loss/1000:.1f}B', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Tariff scenarios chart saved as 'official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png'")

def generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data):
    """Generate monthly volatility heatmap"""
    # Create pivot table for heatmap
    heatmap_data = usa_data.pivot_table(values='value_millions', 
                                        index='year', 
                                        columns='month', 
                                        aggfunc='mean')
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(14, 10))
    
    # Create heatmap
    im = plt.imshow(heatmap_data.values, cmap='RdYlGn', aspect='auto')
    
    # Set ticks and labels
    plt.xticks(range(12), ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun',
                          'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'])
    plt.yticks(range(len(heatmap_data.index)), heatmap_data.index)
    
    # Add colorbar
    cbar = plt.colorbar(im)
    cbar.set_label('Export Value (€ millions)', rotation=270, labelpad=20)
    
    plt.title('Italian Pharmaceutical Exports to USA - Monthly Heatmap\n(2002-2025)', 
              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    plt.xlabel('Month', fontsize=12)
    plt.ylabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    
    # Add value annotations for recent years
    for i, year in enumerate(heatmap_data.index[-5:]):  # Last 5 years
        year_idx = len(heatmap_data.index) - 5 + i
        for j in range(12):
            if not pd.isna(heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]):
                value = heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]
                plt.text(j, year_idx, f'{value:.0f}', ha='center', va='center',
                        color='white' if value < heatmap_data.values.mean() else 'black',
                        fontsize=8, fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_monthly_heatmap.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Monthly heatmap saved as 'official_monthly_heatmap.png'")

generate_timeline_chart(usa_data, world_data)
    generate_market_share_chart(market_share_data)
    generate_growth_comparison_chart(annual_data)
    generate_political_periods_chart(usa_data)
    generate_tariff_scenario_chart(usa_data)
    generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data)

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from datetime import datetime
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Set Italian color scheme
ITALY_GREEN = '#009246'
ITALY_WHITE = '#FFFFFF'
ITALY_RED = '#CE2B37'
USA_BLUE = '#002868'

plt.style.use('default')
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (12, 8)
plt.rcParams['font.size'] = 11

def load_and_process_data():
    """Load and process the pharmaceutical export data"""
    df = pd.read_csv('data/ita_export_usa_world_historical_series.csv')
    
    # Clean and process the data
    df['TIME_PERIOD'] = pd.to_datetime(df['TIME_PERIOD'])
    df['year'] = df['TIME_PERIOD'].dt.year
    df['month'] = df['TIME_PERIOD'].dt.month
    df['value_millions'] = df['OBS_VALUE'] / 1_000_000
    
    # Separate USA and World data
    usa_data = df[df['PARTNER'].str.contains('United States', na=False)].copy()
    world_data = df[df['PARTNER'].str.contains('All countries', na=False)].copy()
    
    # Sort by date
    usa_data = usa_data.sort_values('TIME_PERIOD')
    world_data = world_data.sort_values('TIME_PERIOD')
    
    return df, usa_data, world_data

def calculate_market_share(usa_data, world_data):
    """Calculate USA market share over time"""
    merged = pd.merge(usa_data[['TIME_PERIOD', 'value_millions']], 
                      world_data[['TIME_PERIOD', 'value_millions']], 
                      on='TIME_PERIOD', suffixes=('_usa', '_world'))
    merged['usa_share'] = (merged['value_millions_usa'] / merged['value_millions_world']) * 100
    return merged

def get_political_periods(data):
    """Define political periods for analysis"""
    periods = {
        'Pre-Trump (2002-2016)': data[data['year'] <= 2016],
        'Trump 1.0 (2017-2021)': data[(data['year'] >= 2017) & (data['year'] <= 2020)],
        'Biden (2021-2024)': data[(data['year'] >= 2021) & (data['year'] <= 2024)],
        'Trump 2.0 (2025+)': data[data['year'] >= 2025]
    }
    return periods

def calculate_annual_data(usa_data, world_data):
    """Calculate annual aggregated data"""
    usa_annual = usa_data.groupby('year')['value_millions'].sum().reset_index()
    world_annual = world_data.groupby('year')['value_millions'].sum().reset_index()
    
    annual_merged = pd.merge(usa_annual, world_annual, on='year', suffixes=('_usa', '_world'))
    annual_merged['usa_share'] = (annual_merged['value_millions_usa'] / annual_merged['value_millions_world']) * 100
    annual_merged['rest_world'] = annual_merged['value_millions_world'] - annual_merged['value_millions_usa']
    
    return annual_merged

def generate_timeline_chart(usa_data, world_data):
    """Generate timeline comparison chart"""
    fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 8))
    
    # USA exports (left axis)
    ax1.plot(usa_data['TIME_PERIOD'], usa_data['value_millions'], 
             color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=2.5, label='USA Exports')
    ax1.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    ax1.set_ylabel('USA Exports (€ millions)', color=USA_BLUE, fontsize=12)
    ax1.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor=USA_BLUE)
    ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
    
    # World exports (right axis)
    ax2 = ax1.twinx()
    ax2.plot(world_data['TIME_PERIOD'], world_data['value_millions'], 
             color=ITALY_GREEN, linewidth=2.5, label='World Total Exports')
    ax2.set_ylabel('World Total Exports (€ millions)', color=ITALY_GREEN, fontsize=12)
    ax2.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor=ITALY_GREEN)
    
    # Mark political periods
    ax1.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2021-01-01'), 
                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 1.0')
    ax1.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2025-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2025-12-31'), 
                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 2.0')
    
    plt.title('Italian Pharmaceutical Exports: USA vs World Total\n(Monthly Data 2002-2025)', 
              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    
    # Combine legends
    lines1, labels1 = ax1.get_legend_handles_labels()
    lines2, labels2 = ax2.get_legend_handles_labels()
    ax1.legend(lines1 + lines2, labels1 + labels2, loc='upper left')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_timeline_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Timeline chart saved as 'official_timeline_chart.png'")

def generate_market_share_chart(market_share_data):
    """Generate USA market share evolution chart"""
    plt.figure(figsize=(14, 8))
    
    plt.fill_between(market_share_data['TIME_PERIOD'], market_share_data['usa_share'], 
                     alpha=0.3, color=USA_BLUE)
    plt.plot(market_share_data['TIME_PERIOD'], market_share_data['usa_share'], 
             color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=2.5)
    
    # Mark political periods
    plt.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2021-01-01'), 
                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 1.0')
    plt.axvspan(pd.Timestamp('2025-01-01'), pd.Timestamp('2025-12-31'), 
                alpha=0.1, color=ITALY_RED, label='Trump 2.0')
    
    plt.title('USA Share of Italian Pharmaceutical Exports\n(Monthly Data 2002-2025)', 
              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    plt.xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    plt.ylabel('USA Market Share (%)', fontsize=12)
    plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
    plt.legend()
    
    # Add average line
    avg_share = market_share_data['usa_share'].mean()
    plt.axhline(y=avg_share, color=ITALY_RED, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, 
                label=f'Average: {avg_share:.1f}%')
    plt.legend()
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_market_share_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Market share chart saved as 'official_market_share_chart.png'")

def generate_growth_comparison_chart(annual_data):
    """Generate annual growth rate comparison"""
    # Calculate growth rates
    annual_data['usa_growth'] = annual_data['value_millions_usa'].pct_change() * 100
    annual_data['world_growth'] = annual_data['value_millions_world'].pct_change() * 100
    annual_data['rest_world_growth'] = annual_data['rest_world'].pct_change() * 100
    
    # Filter for years with data
    growth_data = annual_data[annual_data['year'] >= 2003].copy()
    
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 8))
    
    x = np.arange(len(growth_data))
    width = 0.25
    
    bars1 = ax.bar(x - width, growth_data['usa_growth'], width, 
                   label='USA', color=USA_BLUE, alpha=0.8)
    bars2 = ax.bar(x, growth_data['world_growth'], width, 
                   label='World Total', color=ITALY_GREEN, alpha=0.8)
    bars3 = ax.bar(x + width, growth_data['rest_world_growth'], width, 
                   label='Rest of World', color=ITALY_RED, alpha=0.8)
    
    ax.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    ax.set_ylabel('Annual Growth Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax.set_title('Italian Pharmaceutical Export Growth Rates\n(Year-over-Year % Change)', 
                 fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    ax.set_xticks(x)
    ax.set_xticklabels(growth_data['year'], rotation=45)
    ax.legend()
    ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    ax.axhline(y=0, color='black', linestyle='-', alpha=0.5)
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_growth_comparison_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Growth comparison chart saved as 'official_growth_comparison_chart.png'")

def generate_political_periods_chart(usa_data):
    """Generate market dependency by political periods"""
    periods = get_political_periods(usa_data)
    
    # Calculate averages for each period
    period_stats = {}
    for period_name, period_data in periods.items():
        if not period_data.empty:
            avg_value = period_data['value_millions'].mean()
            period_stats[period_name] = avg_value
    
    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 8))
    
    # Pie chart of average monthly exports by period
    sizes = list(period_stats.values())
    labels = list(period_stats.keys())
    colors = [ITALY_GREEN, ITALY_RED, USA_BLUE, '#FF6B35']
    
    wedges, texts, autotexts = ax1.pie(sizes, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%', 
                                       colors=colors, startangle=90)
    ax1.set_title('Average Monthly USA Exports by Political Period\n(€ millions)', 
                  fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    
    # Bar chart comparison
    bars = ax2.bar(range(len(period_stats)), sizes, color=colors, alpha=0.8)
    ax2.set_xlabel('Political Period', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_ylabel('Average Monthly Exports (€ millions)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_title('USA Export Performance by Administration', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax2.set_xticks(range(len(labels)))
    ax2.set_xticklabels(labels, rotation=45, ha='right')
    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    
    # Add value labels on bars
    for bar, value in zip(bars, sizes):
        height = bar.get_height()
        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.01,
                f'€{value:.0f}M', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_political_periods_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Political periods chart saved as 'official_political_periods_chart.png'")

def generate_tariff_scenario_chart(usa_data):
    """Generate tariff impact scenario modeling"""
    # Use recent average (2020-2024) as baseline
    recent_data = usa_data[usa_data['year'] >= 2020]
    baseline_monthly = recent_data['value_millions'].mean()
    baseline_annual = baseline_monthly * 12
    
    # Tariff scenarios
    tariff_rates = [0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30]
    # Assume 50% of tariff rate translates to demand reduction (conservative estimate)
    impact_scenarios = [baseline_annual * (1 - (rate * 0.005)) for rate in tariff_rates]
    revenue_loss = [baseline_annual - scenario for scenario in impact_scenarios]
    
    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 8))
    
    # Scenario projections
    ax1.plot(tariff_rates, impact_scenarios, 'o-', color=USA_BLUE, linewidth=3, markersize=8)
    ax1.axhline(y=baseline_annual, color=ITALY_GREEN, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, 
                label=f'Current Baseline: €{baseline_annual:.1f}B')
    ax1.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax1.set_ylabel('Projected Annual Exports (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
    ax1.set_title('USA Export Projections Under Different Tariff Scenarios', 
                  fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
    ax1.legend()
    
    # Revenue loss
    bars = ax2.bar(tariff_rates[1:], [loss/1000 for loss in revenue_loss[1:]], 
                   color=ITALY_RED, alpha=0.8)
    ax2.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_ylabel('Annual Revenue Loss (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_title('Potential Revenue Loss from US Tariffs', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    
    # Add value labels
    for bar, loss in zip(bars, revenue_loss[1:]):
        height = bar.get_height()
        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.02,
                f'€{loss/1000:.1f}B', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Tariff scenarios chart saved as 'official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png'")

def generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data):
    """Generate monthly volatility heatmap"""
    # Create pivot table for heatmap
    heatmap_data = usa_data.pivot_table(values='value_millions', 
                                        index='year', 
                                        columns='month', 
                                        aggfunc='mean')
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(14, 10))
    
    # Create heatmap
    im = plt.imshow(heatmap_data.values, cmap='RdYlGn', aspect='auto')
    
    # Set ticks and labels
    plt.xticks(range(12), ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun',
                          'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'])
    plt.yticks(range(len(heatmap_data.index)), heatmap_data.index)
    
    # Add colorbar
    cbar = plt.colorbar(im)
    cbar.set_label('Export Value (€ millions)', rotation=270, labelpad=20)
    
    plt.title('Italian Pharmaceutical Exports to USA - Monthly Heatmap\n(2002-2025)', 
              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    plt.xlabel('Month', fontsize=12)
    plt.ylabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    
    # Add value annotations for recent years
    for i, year in enumerate(heatmap_data.index[-5:]):  # Last 5 years
        year_idx = len(heatmap_data.index) - 5 + i
        for j in range(12):
            if not pd.isna(heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]):
                value = heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]
                plt.text(j, year_idx, f'{value:.0f}', ha='center', va='center',
                        color='white' if value < heatmap_data.values.mean() else 'black',
                        fontsize=8, fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_monthly_heatmap.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Monthly heatmap saved as 'official_monthly_heatmap.png'")

def print_key_statistics(usa_data, world_data, market_share_data, annual_data):
    """Print key statistics for presentation"""
    print("\n" + "="*60)
    print("KEY STATISTICS FOR PRESENTATION")
    print("="*60)
    
    # Current market size
    recent_usa = usa_data[usa_data['year'] >= 2020]['value_millions'].mean() * 12
    recent_world = world_data[world_data['year'] >= 2020]['value_millions'].mean() * 12
    usa_share_recent = (recent_usa / recent_world) * 100
    
    print(f"\nMARKET SIZE (2020-2024 Average):")
    print(f"   • USA Market: €{recent_usa:.1f} billion annually")
    print(f"   • World Total: €{recent_world:.1f} billion annually")
    print(f"   • USA Share: {usa_share_recent:.1f}% of total Italian pharma exports")
    
    # Growth trends
    growth_2019_2024_usa = ((usa_data[usa_data['year'] == 2024]['value_millions'].sum() / 
                            usa_data[usa_data['year'] == 2019]['value_millions'].sum()) - 1) * 100
    growth_2019_2024_world = ((world_data[world_data['year'] == 2024]['value_millions'].sum() / 
                              world_data[world_data['year'] == 2019]['value_millions'].sum()) - 1) * 100
    
    print(f"\nGROWTH TRENDS (2019-2024):")
    print(f"   • USA Market Growth: +{growth_2019_2024_usa:.1f}%")
    print(f"   • World Market Growth: +{growth_2019_2024_world:.1f}%")
    print(f"   • USA outpacing world by: {growth_2019_2024_usa - growth_2019_2024_world:.1f} percentage points")
    
    # Political period analysis
    trump1_avg = usa_data[(usa_data['year'] >= 2017) & (usa_data['year'] <= 2020)]['value_millions'].mean()
    biden_avg = usa_data[(usa_data['year'] >= 2021) & (usa_data['year'] <= 2024)]['value_millions'].mean()
    
    print(f"\nPOLITICAL PERIOD COMPARISON:")
    print(f"   • Trump 1.0 (2017-2020): €{trump1_avg:.0f}M monthly average")
    print(f"   • Biden (2021-2024): €{biden_avg:.0f}M monthly average")
    print(f"   • Biden era growth: +{((biden_avg/trump1_avg)-1)*100:.1f}%")
    
    # Risk assessment
    max_monthly = usa_data['value_millions'].max()
    volatility = usa_data['value_millions'].std()
    
    print(f"\nRISK FACTORS:")
    print(f"   • Peak monthly export: €{max_monthly:.0f}M")
    print(f"   • Monthly volatility: ±€{volatility:.0f}M (std dev)")
    print(f"   • At 10% tariff impact: ~€{recent_usa * 0.1:.1f}B annual revenue at risk")
    print(f"   • At 20% tariff impact: ~€{recent_usa * 0.2:.1f}B annual revenue at risk")
    
    print(f"\nKEY INSIGHTS:")
    print(f"   • USA is Italy's {usa_share_recent:.0f}% pharmaceutical export market")
    print(f"   • Strong growth momentum even during political uncertainty")
    print(f"   • High absolute values mean significant revenue exposure to policy changes")
    print(f"   • Seasonal patterns suggest consistent pharmaceutical demand")
    
    print("\n" + "="*60)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    print("Loading and processing Italian pharmaceutical export data...")
    
    # Load data
    df, usa_data, world_data = load_and_process_data()
    market_share_data = calculate_market_share(usa_data, world_data)
    annual_data = calculate_annual_data(usa_data, world_data)
    
    print(f"Data loaded: {len(df)} records from {df['TIME_PERIOD'].min().strftime('%Y-%m')} to {df['TIME_PERIOD'].max().strftime('%Y-%m')}")
    
    # Generate all visualizations
    print("\nGenerating visualizations...")
    
    generate_timeline_chart(usa_data, world_data)
    generate_market_share_chart(market_share_data)
    generate_growth_comparison_chart(annual_data)
    generate_political_periods_chart(usa_data)
    generate_tariff_scenario_chart(usa_data)
    generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data)
    
    # Print statistics
    print_key_statistics(usa_data, world_data, market_share_data, annual_data)
    
    print("\nAll visualizations completed!")
    print("Files created:")
    print("   • official_timeline_chart.png")
    print("   • official_market_share_chart.png") 
    print("   • official_growth_comparison_chart.png")
    print("   • official_political_periods_chart.png")
    print("   • official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png")
    print("   • official_monthly_heatmap.png")

    ax1.legend()
    
    # Revenue loss
    bars = ax2.bar(tariff_rates[1:], [loss/1000 for loss in revenue_loss[1:]], 
                   color=ITALY_RED, alpha=0.8)
    ax2.set_xlabel('Tariff Rate (%)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_ylabel('Annual Revenue Loss (€ billions)', fontsize=12)
    ax2.set_title('Potential Revenue Loss from US Tariffs', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
    ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3, axis='y')
    
    # Add value labels
    for bar, loss in zip(bars, revenue_loss[1:]):
        height = bar.get_height()
        ax2.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + height*0.02,
                f'€{loss/1000:.1f}B', ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Tariff scenarios chart saved as 'official_tariff_scenarios_chart.png'")

def generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data):
    """Generate monthly volatility heatmap"""
    # Create pivot table for heatmap
    heatmap_data = usa_data.pivot_table(values='value_millions', 
                                        index='year', 
                                        columns='month', 
                                        aggfunc='mean')
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(14, 10))
    
    # Create heatmap
    im = plt.imshow(heatmap_data.values, cmap='RdYlGn', aspect='auto')
    
    # Set ticks and labels
    plt.xticks(range(12), ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun',
                          'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'])
    plt.yticks(range(len(heatmap_data.index)), heatmap_data.index)
    
    # Add colorbar
    cbar = plt.colorbar(im)
    cbar.set_label('Export Value (€ millions)', rotation=270, labelpad=20)
    
    plt.title('Italian Pharmaceutical Exports to USA - Monthly Heatmap\n(2002-2025)', 
              fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    plt.xlabel('Month', fontsize=12)
    plt.ylabel('Year', fontsize=12)
    
    # Add value annotations for recent years
    for i, year in enumerate(heatmap_data.index[-5:]):  # Last 5 years
        year_idx = len(heatmap_data.index) - 5 + i
        for j in range(12):
            if not pd.isna(heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]):
                value = heatmap_data.iloc[year_idx, j]
                plt.text(j, year_idx, f'{value:.0f}', ha='center', va='center',
                        color='white' if value < heatmap_data.values.mean() else 'black',
                        fontsize=8, fontweight='bold')
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.savefig('official_monthly_heatmap.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
    plt.show()
    
    print("Monthly heatmap saved as 'official_monthly_heatmap.png'")

generate_timeline_chart(usa_data, world_data)
    generate_market_share_chart(market_share_data)
    generate_growth_comparison_chart(annual_data)
    generate_political_periods_chart(usa_data)
    generate_tariff_scenario_chart(usa_data)
    generate_monthly_heatmap(usa_data)
